relate work.comparisons with related methods: The paper compares its Group Conformity Score (GCS) using contextual embeddings to previous measures like BOW partisanship, highlighting improved semantic capture and applicability to social media contexts.

high_level_summary.summary of this paper: This paper examines religious polarization on Indian Twitter during COVID-19, introducing the Group Conformity Score (GCS) using contextualized tweet embeddings to study intergroup interactions between religious majority and minority groups.
high_level_summary.research purpose: The research aims to understand how intergroup interactions on social media influence polarization amidst crises, specifically during the COVID-19 pandemic, by introducing a novel metric to measure group conformities.
high_level_summary.research challenge: Determining the nuanced effects of intergroup interactions on polarization, considering factors like event type, emotion, and user engagement.
high_level_summary.conclusion: Intergroup interactions generally reduce polarization, though this effect varies across events and user group alignments, with minority groups experiencing increased polarization during communal events.

Method.description: The study introduces a Group Conformity Score (GCS) leveraging contextualized embeddings from tweets to measure users' alignment with their group during the COVID-19 crisis.
Method.feature processing: The study incorporates contextualized embeddings using a pre-trained model to capture the semantics of religiously charged tweets beyond mere word frequency.
Method.model: The GCS model uses sentence transformers to map tweets into a semantic vector space, computing a conformity score relative to group centroids.

datasets: Global Reactions to COVID-19 on Twitter
Experiments.setup: Tweets from COVID-19 events specific to Indian contexts were analyzed, separated by religious affiliations inferred from usernames.
Experiments.results: Intergroup interaction generally led to decreased polarization, except during communal events or politically charged instances.

conclusion.summary: Intergroup interactions on social media can serve to decrease polarization except during highly communalized events, where they may heighten minority group conformities.
conclusion.future work: Future research could explore applying the GCS measure to other forms of identity-based polarization on different social media platforms or real-world political contexts.
